See the original theme song here, whose imagery (which is highly symbolic â€” go watch the show! it's amazing) has been imitated in this video: https://youtu.be/WJeeA_O88Zw

Round the milklighted mist
ÎºÎµÎºÎ±Î»Ï…Î¼Î¼Î­Î½Î± Ï€Î¬Î½Ï„â€™ á¼Ï†Î¬Î½Î·.
all that has been hidden is revealed.

Long ago burdensome forgetfulness and memory
Ï€Î¿á¿– Ï†Î­ÏÎµÏ„Î±Î¹;Â  Â á½Ï€Î¿Î¹ Ï„á½° Ï„Î­Î»Î·;
where will they be carried off to?  To what point the end?
Î•á¼° Î¼á½´ ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ á½•Ï€Î±Ï, Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Î´â€™ Î¿á½ ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ á½„Î½Î±Ï;
If not in reality, why not in dreams?

ÎŸá½ÏÎ¯Ï‰Î¹ á¼Î³á½¼
Born on a fair
Îµá½”ÏÏ‰Î¹ Î´â€™ á¼ Ï‡Î¸Îµá½¶Ï‚Â  Â 
eastern wind 
Î´Î¹á½° Ï€Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ¯Î»Ï‰Î½ Ï†ÏÎ»Î»Ï‰Î½
through many-colored leaves
Ï‡Î¿ÏÎµÏÏ‰ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ¿Ï†á¿†Î¹,
I dance in a swirl,
Ï‡Ïá¿¡ÏƒÎµá¿– Î¼Î½Î®Î¼Î·Î¹,
golden memory,
Î³Î»Ï…ÎºÏÏ„Î±Ï„Î± ÏˆÎµÏ…Î´á¿† Ï€Î»Î¬ÏƒÏƒÏ‰Î½.
sculpting the loveliest lies.

Commentary
This translation seeks to match long and short syllables (meter) to the long and short notes of the original song; additionally â€” and I believe this is the first time anyone has attempted this since antiquity â€” the pitch accent also corresponds to the pitches of the melody.  See here how Ancient Greek sheet music's melodies follow the natural pitches of the lyrics:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek_accent#Evidence_from_music

This is how we know that pitch accent is a part of the Ancient Greek lanugage until about the 4th century AD.

á¼€Ì„á½³ÏÎ± "air/mist" â€” in Homer this more often means mist.
Î³Î±Î»Î±ÎºÏ„Î¿Ï†Î±á¿† "milklighted" â€” imagine my delight to have found this work which so closely matches the original lyric!
á¼Ï†á½±Î½Î· "is revealed / appears" â€”Â gnomic aorist.
Î»á½µÎ¸Î· "forgetfullness" â€” in Greek mythology, the dead would drink of the River Lethe to forget their living existence.
Î¿á½Ïá½·Ï‰Î¹...Îµá½”ÏÏ‰Î¹ "the fair east wind" â€” the east wind, associated with autumn, is *not* fair and gentle, hence the deliberate contrast here; nevertheless the east wind drives one to the west, towards the setting sun (given the themes of Over the Garden Wall, I think you can see what I was getting at).

The pronunciation used is that of Classical Attic, or the best I could manage while also trying to sing this song â€” as I'm not a trained singer, this was the best compromise I could muster.

I hope you enjoy it!  I hope it inspires you to learn Ancient Greek (and also to watch Over the Garden Wall if you haven't seen it yet!), and to write your own translations, covers, and poetry in Ancient Greek that make full use of phonemic syllable length, meter, and pitch accent.

(did you spot the turtle?)

title: Latin in Action! ep.2 |  Taking, Putting, Drinking
description:
Learn Latin through Comprehensible Input!  Latin in Action (the sister series to Ancient Greek in Action)  teaches you the language entirely through the medium of Latin, an approach called Comprehensible Input.  By watching every video in this series in order, you should be able to understand everything after watching a video two or three times.  In this way, you will build a strong foundation in LATIN.  ("Latin" as a term encompasses the grammar and vocabulary of both Classical Latin and Ecclesiastical Latin.) ğŸ›ï¸ 

ğŸ¢ LATIN IN ACTION ğŸ¦‰ 
by Luke Amadeus Ranieri ğŸ¦‚ L. AmÄdeus RÄniÄ“rius 

In this video, the only words you need to acquire are the future, present, and simple-past of the verbs of taking, drinking, putting down, which are printed on the screen.  Other words are uttered in the video which are not essential to acquire at this time; merely concern yourself with learning by heart the forms "I will throw, I throw, I threw," etc.

Once you have seen this video enough times, repeat these verbs from memory every time you take something or put it down, and every time you take a drink. Find opportunities to use these verbs, joining your utterances to physical actions that will ingrain them into long-term memory.

The full script, while unnecessary for the scope of this video as a Comprehensible Input tool, is available for my Patreon supporters: https://www.patreon.com/posts/142087911

The pronunciation you hear is that of Classical Latin, a literary period from the 1st century BC to the 2nd century AD.  See my various videos on Latin pronunciation both on this channel: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLXC2COSA2yQjJD-c1kKU6-TKlzErrGxmh

 and on my other channel polÃ½MATHY: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLQQL5IeNgck2Ytcf9Sz3OSTVFe7MOM7u9


NotÄ bene:  Both Latin in Action and Ancient Greek in Action are deliberately meant to cover more or less the same basic vocabulary and situations.  My dream is for there to be a hundred videos in both series, giving people with no experience in either language the opportunity to achieve basic fluency in both.

Latin in Action musical theme: "Best of Both Worlds" by Zac Nelson.

Î£Î±Ï‚ ÎµÏ…Ï‡Î±ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Ï Î³Î¹Î± Ï„Î·Î½ Ï…Ï€Î¿Î¼Î¿Î½Î® ÎºÎ±Î¹ Ï„Î·Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î½ÏŒÎ·ÏƒÎ® ÏƒÎ±Ï‚. ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡· ğŸ˜Š

Î£Î·Î¼Îµá½·Ï‰ÏƒÎ±Î¹:  This is a reboot of the AGIA series which originally ran for twelve episodes from 2020-2021.  Those videos were designed to prepare the viewer to read chapter 1 of Athenaze.  The new incarnation of the series will follow a paedagogical trajectory independent of any other book or course.  The scope of the new AGIA is to help the viewer acquire the Ancient Greek language primarily through auditory and visual context with the goal of rendering key points of each episode being fully comprehensible input.  The intent is for the viewer to form an internal representation of Ancient Greek that builds a foundation of fluency in listening, and, as a consequence, in reading.

title: How to write Greek letters | Tutorial in Ancient Greek! | Î Ï‰Í‚Ï‚ Î³ÏÎ±ÌÏ†ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Ï„Î±Ì€ Î•Ì”Î»Î»Î·Î½Î¹ÎºÎ±Ì€ Î³ÏÎ±ÌÎ¼Î¼Î±Ï„Î±
description:
In this tutorial, taught in Ancient Greek spoken in the Classical Attic Pronunciation, I show you how to write all 24 letters of the Greek alphabet, including their ancient names (which occasionally differ a lot from their modern names), along with some tips for pronunciation.

If you're new to Greek, don't worry if you don't understand everything I say; pay attention to how the letters are written, and and learn the letters' names in alphabetical order.

If you're interested in taking one of my classes, you'll find them listed here:
https://lukeranieri.com/classes/

title: Camillus, Columbus RÅmÄnus, Cap.2: FrÄtrÄ“s et SorÅrÄ“s
description:
This is the first draft of a new introductory Latin reader called CAMILLVS Â· COLVMBVS ROMANVS, a story about the odyssey of a pigeon in Ancient Rome whose exploits carry him from the Eternal City to the edges of the Empire.  This book will serve as an introduction to the Latin language as well as Roman history, culture, literature, and society.

ğŸ™ The audio has been made available for download to all my Patreon supporters: https://www.patreon.com/posts/123604218

ğŸ“• The PDF, exercises, additional audio, and grammatical notes are available to Patreon supporters at a higher tier: https://www.patreon.com/posts/camillus-pdfs-123618459

ğŸ•Šï¸ Irene La Preziosa (  @irenelapreziosa  ) and I lend our voices to this chapter.

The approach of CAMILLVS is much inspired by Colin Gorrie's ÅŒsweald Bera: An Introduction to Old English ( https://youtu.be/1IFyYozfM38 ), where the focus is put on the story most of all, and the vocabulary and grammar used is for the purpose of telling that story.  This approach seems to be more effective at imparting key vocabulary and grammar into long-term memory than traditional readers that build a story around a grammatical progression and chapters on thematic vocabulary.  Yet more credit is due to my colleague Logan KilpelÃ¤, who, in an as-yet unpublished work, has pioneered not only a story-focused approach, but also the use of extensive images and deictic boxes.  For this reason, I call this approach KilpelÃ¤tion (as explained in the introduction to my KilpelÃ¤ted edition of Thrasymachus called Thrasymachus' Catabasis: https://bit.ly/thrasymachuscatabasis ).  Further thanks are due to Raphael Turrigiano, who in collaboration with Logan KilpelÃ¤ has offered great insights to the paedagogical utility of these techniques, and whose guidance has as a result been of great value in the present work.

This video presents a draft of the reader, which will eventually be made available as a printed book.

The character of Camillus is inspired by a real-life pigeon that Irene La Preziosa and I rescued in Rome whom we named Camillo, recounted here in Ancient Greek on my podcast Legio XIII:  https://youtu.be/7VwgLu1WtOM

title: NON AVRO SED FERRO: a graphic novel in LATIN | Interview with the Authors
description:
NON AVRO SED FERRO by NUBES is a new graphic novel that follows the exploits of Furius Camillus, from the capture of the Veii to the liberation of the siege by the Gauls of Brennus (based on Plutarch and Livy).  The narrative glue are two minor historical characters, Pontius Cominius and Marcus Cedicius, whose lives have been dramatized in a manner reminiscent of Titus Pullo and Lucius Vorenus in the HBO series "ROME."

Support the NON AVRO SED FERRO project by NUBES and preorder before April 30th, 2025: https://www.nubes.live/prodotto/non-auro-sed-ferro/  â¬…ï¸ ğŸ“•

title: Camillus, Columbus RÅmÄnus, Cap.1: ÅŒvum et Columba
description:
This is the first draft of a new introductory Latin reader called CAMILLVS Â· COLVMBVS ROMANVS, a story about the odyssey of a pigeon in Ancient Rome whose exploits carry him from the Eternal City to the edges of the Empire.  This book will serve as an introduction to the Latin language as well as Roman history, culture, literature, and society.

ğŸ™ The audio has been made available for download to all my Patreon supporters: https://www.patreon.com/posts/123604218

ğŸ“• The PDF, exercises, additional audio, and grammatical notes are available to Patreon supporters at a higher tier: https://www.patreon.com/posts/123618459

ğŸ•Šï¸ Irene La Preziosa (  @irenelapreziosa  ) and I lend our voices to this chapter.

The approach of CAMILLVS is much inspired by Colin Gorrie's ÅŒsweald Bera: An Introduction to Old English ( https://youtu.be/1IFyYozfM38 ), where the focus is put on the story most of all, and the vocabulary and grammar used is for the purpose of telling that story.  This approach seems to be more effective at imparting key vocabulary and grammar into long-term memory than traditional readers that build a story around a grammatical progression and chapters on thematic vocabulary.  Yet more credit is due to my colleague Logan KilpelÃ¤, who, in an as-yet unpublished work, has pioneered not only a story-focused approach, but also the use of extensive images and deictic boxes.  For this reason, I call this approach KilpelÃ¤tion (as explained in the introduction to my KilpelÃ¤ted edition of Thrasymachus called Thrasymachus' Catabasis: https://bit.ly/thrasymachuscatabasis ).  Further thanks are due to Raphael Turrigiano, who in collaboration with Logan KilpelÃ¤ has offered great insights to the paedagogical utility of these techniques, and whose guidance has as a result been of great value in the present work.

This video presents a draft of the reader, which will eventually be made available as a printed book.

The character of Camillus is inspired by a real-life pigeon that Irene La Preziosa and I rescued in Rome whom we named Camillo, recounted here in Ancient Greek on my podcast Legio XIII:  https://youtu.be/7VwgLu1WtOM

title: Talk in Latin: Technological Progress Is Not Inevitable | Living Latin in NYC 2024
description:
In this talk given at Paideia's Living Latin in NYC 2024, I present my observation that technological progress is not inevitable, exhorting those of us who know and appreciate ancient literature and history, and therefore know how easy it is for a civilization to stagnate and collapse, to teach what we know to anyone who is willing, including and especially the engineers, the doctors, the statesmen, the scientists of the world who, inspired by the accomplishments of the past, might right along with us carry on the patrimony of classical literature and history, for they are the very people in a position to craft our best future.

Discount Registration for Living Latin in New York City 2025 at this link if you regester by Feb. 1 , 2025! :
https://www.paideiainstitute.org/llinyc_2025_registration_payment_ranieri

N.B. This is not a sponsorship from Paideia; that is, I don't get any benefit from sharing this link with you â€”Â my only wish is that as many people as possible come to LLiNYC 2025 and have a great time there.

title: Reading Greek with Luke, An Ephesian Tale 1.3
description:
Welcome to Reading Greek with Luke, in which I read to you in Ancient Greek, and ask you questions about the reading, much as a teacher in a classroom.  This video will help train your listening and reading comprehension, as well as your speaking proficiency.

Let's read *An Ephesian Tale* ! one of the earliest surviving Ancient Greek novels, by Xenophon of Ephesus who lived in the 1st or 2nd century AD.  This novel involves romance, action, and adventure, and is thought to have been an inspiration to Shakespeare among others.

*How you might use this video lesson:*
1. Click or tap on the part of the reading in the timeline (labeled Î¼á½³ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î±Ê¹ (part 1), Î¼á½³ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î²Ê¹ (part 2), Î¼á½³ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î³Ê¹ (part 3), etc.) and listen to the recitation *without* looking at the text.  Before I start asking questions about the reading, go back to the beginning of that part of the reading, and listen once again without seeing the text.
2. Listen to that part of the reading a third time, but now do so while reading along with the text.
3. Pause the video and recite the text aloud on your own.
4. Listen to my questions, and attempt to answer them aloud in Ancient Greek by finding the answer in the text.  (You may pause the video if you need more time to answer.)

You may add or skip steps as is appropriate for your level.  The reason not to look at the text, but only listen two times in a row, is to help your brain isolate key words.  For people not used to hearing Ancient Greek spoken to them without immediate reference to the written word, this will be challenging!  But that's the idea: it challenges your brain to understand exclusively through auditory input.  Then, when you hear the same part of the text a second time, you'll get much more.  It'll surprise you!  By the end of the video, you'll understand what you're hearing far better than when you started.  

No matter what your current level in Ancient Greek, this will likely present some challenge: not only do you have to get used to receiving auditory-only input (which is rare for anyone who works with an ancient language), but you will have to get used to the story, my manner of reading, and also the Classical Attic Pronunciation (discussed here: https://youtu.be/dQBpwKWnZAo ).

The result of this exercise will be much improved reading comprehension in Ancient Greek that you can utilize with any text you encounter.  You may even learn to speak a little too!

The printed book I am using may be found on Amazon here (purchasing via this affiliated link brings a very small commision to support the channel): https://amzn.to/4f0QA1b
This edition by C. T. Hadavas is exceptional because it has every new word calqued in English on the same page as the main text (I don't show you those parts of the pages).

However, the original text that you see in the video, written by Xenophon of Ephesus, is available for free and can be found online, such as at Perseus: https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2008.01.0649

My inspiration for this video series comes in part from my colleague Adrian Hundhausen, author of the Pharos Thematic Guide to Ancient Greek Vocabulary ( https://amzn.to/3A5iVV5 ) who teaches Ancient Greek in this fashion.  See our interview here: https://youtu.be/RjaPw7K_JJs

The other source of my inspiration for this series is from my colleagues at the Ancient Language Institute who have taught me so much about Second Language Acquisition and paedogogy in general.

I discuss how you can accomplish this technique solo with any text in this video: https://youtu.be/wpxfXiWqnlg

title: Reading Latin with Luke, Eighteen Roman Letters #2 - Cicero, Ad Atticum 5.1 (GOSSIP!)
description:
Welcome to Reading Latin with Luke, in which I read to you in Latin, and ask you questions about the reading, much as a teacher in a classroom.  This video will help train your listening and reading comprehension, as well as your speaking proficiency.

Let's read *Eighteen Roman Letters*, edited by Theodore Horn in 1937, which contains selected letters by Cicero, Seneca, Pliny, and others.  These letters were selected by Horn to elucidate to the reader important historical events, characters, and the lives of the Ancient Romans.

*How you might use this video lesson:*
1. Click or tap on the part of the reading in the timeline (labeled pars i, pars ii, pars iii, etc.) and listen to the recitation *without* looking at the text.  Before I start asking questions about the reading, go back to the beginning of that part of the reading, and listen once again without seeing the text.
2. Listen to that part of the reading a third time, but now do so while reading along with the text.
3. Pause the video and recite the text aloud on your own.
4. Listen to my questions, and attempt to answer them aloud in Latin by finding the answer in the text.  (You may pause the video if you need more time to answer.)

You may add or skip steps as is appropriate for your level.  The reason not to look at the text, but only listen two times in a row, is to help your brain isolate key words.  For people not used to hearing Latin spoken to them without immediate reference to the written word, this will be challenging!  But that's the idea: it challenges your brain to understand exclusively through auditory input.  Then, when you hear the same part of the text a second time, you'll get much more.  It'll surprise you!  By the end of the video, you'll understand what you're hearing far better than when you started.  

No matter what your current level in Latin, this will likely present some challenge: not only do you have to get used to receiving auditory-only input (which is rare for anyone who works with an ancient language), but you will have to get used to the characters and events, my manner of reading, and also the Classical Latin Pronunciation if you are unfamiliar with it.

The result of this exercise will be much improved reading comprehension in Latin that you can utilize with any text you encounter.  You may even learn to speak a little too!

My inspiration for this video series comes in part from my colleague Adrian Hundhausen, author of the Pharos Thematic Guide to Ancient Greek Vocabulary ( https://amzn.to/3A5iVV5 ) who teaches Ancient Greek in this fashion.  See our interview here: https://youtu.be/RjaPw7K_JJs

The other source of my inspiration for this series is from my colleagues at the Ancient Language Institute who have taught me so much about Second Language Acquisition and paedogogy in general.

I discuss how you can accomplish this technique solo with any text in this video: https://youtu.be/wpxfXiWqnlg

However, the original text that you see in the video, written by Xenophon of Ephesus, is available for free and can be found online, such as at Perseus: https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2008.01.0649

My inspiration for this video series comes in part from my colleague Adrian Hundhausen, author of the Pharos Thematic Guide to Ancient Greek Vocabulary ( https://amzn.to/3A5iVV5 ) who teaches Ancient Greek in this fashion.  See our interview here: https://youtu.be/RjaPw7K_JJs

The other source of my inspiration for this series is from my colleagues at the Ancient Language Institute who have taught me so much about Second Language Acquisition and paedogogy in general.

I discuss how you can accomplish this technique solo with any text in this video: https://youtu.be/wpxfXiWqnlg

title: Reading Latin with Luke, Eighteen Roman Letters #1 - Cicero, Ad Familiares 14.1
description:
Welcome to Reading Latin with Luke, in which I read to you in Latin, and ask you questions about the reading, much as a teacher in a classroom.  This video will help train your listening and reading comprehension, as well as your speaking proficiency.

Let's read *Eighteen Roman Letters*, edited by Theodore Horn in 1937, which contains selected letters by Cicero, Seneca, Pliny, and others.  These letters were selected by Horn to elucidate to the reader important historical events, characters, and the lives of the Ancient Romans.

*How you might use this video lesson:*
1. Click or tap on the part of the reading in the timeline (labeled pars i, pars ii, pars iii, etc.) and listen to the recitation *without* looking at the text.  Before I start asking questions about the reading, go back to the beginning of that part of the reading, and listen once again without seeing the text.
2. Listen to that part of the reading a third time, but now do so while reading along with the text.
3. Pause the video and recite the text aloud on your own.
4. Listen to my questions, and attempt to answer them aloud in Latin by finding the answer in the text.  (You may pause the video if you need more time to answer.)

You may add or skip steps as is appropriate for your level.  The reason not to look at the text, but only listen two times in a row, is to help your brain isolate key words.  For people not used to hearing Latin spoken to them without immediate reference to the written word, this will be challenging!  But that's the idea: it challenges your brain to understand exclusively through auditory input.  Then, when you hear the same part of the text a second time, you'll get much more.  It'll surprise you!  By the end of the video, you'll understand what you're hearing far better than when you started.  

No matter what your current level in Latin, this will likely present some challenge: not only do you have to get used to receiving auditory-only input (which is rare for anyone who works with an ancient language), but you will have to get used to the characters and events, my manner of reading, and also the Classical Latin Pronunciation if you are unfamiliar with it.

The result of this exercise will be much improved reading comprehension in Latin that you can utilize with any text you encounter.  You may even learn to speak a little too!

My inspiration for this video series comes in part from my colleague Adrian Hundhausen, author of the Pharos Thematic Guide to Ancient Greek Vocabulary ( https://amzn.to/3A5iVV5 ) who teaches Ancient Greek in this fashion.  See our interview here: https://youtu.be/RjaPw7K_JJs

The other source of my inspiration for this series is from my colleagues at the Ancient Language Institute who have taught me so much about Second Language Acquisition and paedogogy in general.

I discuss how you can accomplish this technique solo with any text in this video: https://youtu.be/wpxfXiWqnlg

title: The Kephalos Method to Homer - Methodus Kephali ad Homerum
description:
[EN] Homeric Greek is rather difficult even for those comfortable with Classical and Koine Greek.  Yet the Iliad and the Odyssey are among the most important works of Western literature.  What's the solution?  In this video, I will tell you about what I call the Kephalos Method to Homer.

title: Colossus of Constantine Tour in Latin ğŸ› Rome, Italy
description:
The Colossus of Constastine has been rebuilt in a full scale replica, which may be visited in 2024 in the garden of Villa Caffarelli in Rome, Italy.  This 21st century recreation based on the fragments of the original found in the Roman Forum in the 1400s is an astounding way to get a sense of the massive scale of Ancient Roman art and architecture.  While Constantine is hailed as the first "Christian" emperor, is that title really deserved? 

Support the MAXENTIUS: POSTREMUS ROMULUS Kickstarter and get your copy before everyone else at this link:
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/originespictae/maxentius-postremus-romulus?ref=3rqsqt

title: Maxentius: the Emperor's secret history revealed
description:
The true history of Emperor Maxentius: revealed in the next graphic novel by NUBES!  Much of what Constantine takes credit for is actually due to the deeds of Maxentius: not just the great Basilica in the Roman Forum, but also his laws and acts with respect to Christians, which we now know due to new historical research. Learn more in this interview in Latin with some of the authors!

title: Join me at Living Latin in New York City 2024!
description:
Join me at Living Latin (and Ancient Greek) in New York City 2024! Register before Feb. 1 at this link to get $50 off the $180 registration fee: â€‹https://www.paideiainstitute.org/llinyc_registration_payment_speakers
Meaning just $130 to register. I don't get any money if you sign up, but I'm really happy that Paideia has offered this discount to my audience â€” the more the merrier!

The price goes up after Feb. 1, so register by Jan. 31 to take advantage of the "avis mÄtÅ«tÄ«na" (early bird) special!

Living Latin in New York City is an annual conference of Classics professors, researchers, students, and enthusiasts who enjoy using spoken Latin and Ancient Greek in their studies and classes.  Everyone may participate from beginner to advanced.  The two-day conference includes talks given entirely in Latin and Ancient Greek, as well as reading and discussion in small groups where a bit of ancient literature is read aloud together and discussed in that language.  It's amazing! It's a very special and unique event.  I hope to see you there!

title: Roman Legionary gives speech on Roman Triumph at Living Latin in New York City âš”ï¸  Â· Legionarius Â·
description:
Roman Legionary Decimus Helvidius Rufus, having been transported from the early 2nd century AD to the present, gives a talk at the Paideia Institute's Living Latin in New York City (February 19, 2023) on the Roman Triumph, Trajan's Column, and the famous Lorica Segmentata armor he wears as an Imperial Legionary.

*Subtitles in Latin and English.*

Join me at Living Latin in New York City 2024! Use this link to get $50 off the $180 registration fee: https://www.paideiainstitute.org/llinyc_registration_payment_speakers
I don't get any money if you sign up, but I'm happy to be able to offer my audience such a huge discount to this one-of-a-kind event.  NÅs vidÄ“bimus illÄ«c!  See you there!

NOTES ON THE ANCIENT ROMAN ACCENT
This was an especially fun thing to imagine and put into practice.  Many have often asked what an Ancient Roman accent would sound like English.  The accent I gave Rufus was a combination of a few ideas:

Italian:
The foundation is essentially a highly stereotypical Italian accent.  This includes some intonational characteristics, or how I say â€œokay,â€ and a few other factors.  Indeed, when I speak Latin, I try to employ Italian-like intonation and oral posture â€” but itâ€™s important to say that I fall well short of my intended goal in my actual production of spoken Latin, especially in an uncontrolled environment like the streets of New York.

Classical Latin phonology:
I reverted the Italian base to Classical Latin wherever in made sense: v is /w/, final /i/ /o/ /u/ are frequently lengthened, s is retracted [sÌ ], and th is [tÊ°], for example â€œvery nice to meet youâ€ [ËˆwÉ›.riË naÍ¡eÌ¯sÌ  tuË miËt juË] or â€œthanks I do to youâ€ (calqued from Latin grÄtiÄs tibi agÅ) [tÊ°É›ËÅ‹ksÌ  aÍ¡eÌ¯ duË tuË juË], as if they were written phonetically in Classical Latin orthography â€œverÄ« naes tÅ« mÄ«t jÅ«,â€ â€œthÄ“nx ae dÅ« tÅ« jÅ«.â€  Latin also permits final consonants -s, -n, -t, -nt, unlike Italian (where there is an audible schwa vowel following in stereotypical Italian accents), but not final -m, hence â€œI am strongâ€ (valeÅ) [aÍ¡eÌ¯ Ã£ strÉ”n] or [aÍ¡eÌ¯ áº½ strÉ”n].

Latin idiom and syntax:
Rufus tends not to use articles in English, as articles are not part of the Latin language. I also calqued many Latin idioms into English, such as â€œthanks I do to youâ€ from grÄtiÄs tibi agÅ, â€œwhat is name to you?â€ quid est tibi nÅmen?, â€œbeautifully!â€ pulchrÄ“!, â€œthe most beautifully!â€ pulcherrimÄ“!, â€œoptimally!â€ optimÄ“!, â€œminimallyâ€ minimÄ“; or randomly inserting Latin grammar into the English, such as the dative case in â€œto the dominae.â€  I also attempted to spontaneously not â€œknowâ€ how to say things in English, trying my best to imagine the challenges that a native Latin speaker would undergo.

The result is an accent that sounds like a strange mix of Italian (the intonation), Slavic (inconsistent use of articles), Spanish (not as many schwas after final consonants), and Greek (retracted s).

Over the course of the day before we went to New York to film, I spent a few hours speaking this way, practicing the accent with my wonderful fiancÃ©e â€”Â who did such an amazing job recording this whole video â€” and she generously laughed at each one of my silly jokes or weird ways of speaking.  If I had spent more time practicing the accent, I bet it would have been a lot more consistent and a much more â€œauthenticâ€ representation of how Ancient Romans might have sounded in Modern English.  But Iâ€™m happy with the result, and itâ€™s great that so many of you have found it entertaining as well.

title: The Iliad in 8 Greek Pronunciations with Pronunciation Guide âš”ï¸ Ilias I.1-7 (English and Latin subs)
description:
What did the Iliad sound like in Ancient Greek? In this video, I will show you how to recite the first lines of Homer's epic in Classical Attic Pronuciation, Koine Pronunciation, and Modern Greek Pronuciation.  Since Koine Greek underwent so many attested changes between Classical and Mediaeval Greek, I have divided these transformations into six pronunciation conventions, part of a system called "Lucian Pronunciation," named after Lucian of Samosata, one of the great authors of the Koine Period.  In this video, I teach you how the phonology of Greek changed from the 6th century BC to the 6th century AD, and the pronunciation variants you can choose from for your own scholarship.

Support the channel by purchasing my audiobook "Judgement of the Goddesses" by Lucian of Samosata recited in all six variants of Lucian Pronunciation: https://luke-ranieri.myshopify.com/collections/frontpage/products/lucians-judgement-of-the-goddesses-in-6-ancient-greek-pronunciations ğŸ“•ğŸ™

description:

Their conversation is suddenly interrupted, however, by a local with a chip on his shoulder. The story then takes a turn for the unexpected. 

ğŸ’¬ Subtitles available in English & Latin! ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ ğŸ¦… ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡¹  

LEGIONARIVS
Written & Performed by Luke Amadeus Ranieri. Directed by Irene La Preziosa @irenelapreziosa 

The ancient Germanic character is speaking Gothic (and Latin with a reconstructed Gothic accent according to ancient Gothic's phonotactic limitations), Gothic being the oldest attested and complete Germanic language from antiquity. His lines were taken from words and phrases in the Gothic Bible and rearranged for the dialogue in the video. He speaks in the reconstruction Gothic pronunciation of the time of Ulfilas. While Gothic like this would have be heard readily more to the east and a couple centuries later than these LEGIONARIVS scenes (which take place in the early 2nd century AD in Germania Inferior), its existence a bit earlier is plausible, it is at least representative of an ancient Germanic voice, which is what the scene called for.

title: What Classical Attic ACTUALLY sounded like ğŸ¤¯ Vulgar Attic pronunciation (English & Latin subtitles)
description:
What was the REAL pronunciation of the ancient Athenians in the 5th and 4th centuries BC? While Sydney Allen's famous VOX GRAECA is a useful start, we know the real story is MUCH more interesting, thanks to philologist Sven-Tage Teodorsson. But how different was it from the usual understanding the Restored Classical Pronunciation of Attic? It was crazier than you think! Watch and find out. Leave a comment if your mind was blown ğŸ¤¯

title: Join me at Living Latin & Ancient Greek in NYC 2023! ğŸ™ï¸ Paideia LLiNYC 2023
description:
Register for Living Latin (& Ancient Greek!) in New York City, Feb. 18-19, 2023, at this link using the $50 discount code *SCORPIOMARTIANUS* https://form.123formbuilder.com/2182816/form

More about LLiNYC here: https://www.paideiainstitute.org/living_latin_in_new_york_city

See my vlog from LLiNYC 2019 here: https://youtu.be/LE1Mg7Vq9pI

And my talk from LLiNYC 2020 here: https://youtu.be/c_Giy_LHAlU

Living Latin in New York City 2023 is a two-day Living Latin conference in Manhattan. The conference is designed to allow teachers and students of Latin to explore and practice the active use of the ancient languages in a classroom setting. Held in historic Regis High School on Manhattanâ€™s Upper East Side, the program includes lectures in Latin on the conference theme and smaller sessions in which participants practice speaking Latin themselves. The conference also offers optional spoken Ancient Greek sessions and lectures. Daily coffee hours allow for informal contact and exchange with other participants.

title: Oogie Boogie's Song, in LATIN! Nightmare Before Christmas (lyrics: Stefano Vittori) Songs in Latin
description:
The Nightmare Before Christmas in Latin! Incubus Ante NÄtÄlem. 
OOGIE BOOGIE'S SONG Â· ULULONIS CARMEN
lyrical translation by Stefano RVMAK Vittori ğŸŒ 
https://www.youtube.com/rvmak
performed by Chris PERNOX Davis ğŸŒš
https://www.youtube.com/pernox
Luke SCORPIO Ranieri ğŸ¦‚ 
https://youtube.com/ScorpioMartianus

This unique and fascinating performance of the beloved song from Danny Elfman and Tim Burton's 1993 "The Nightmare Before Christmas" incorporates *both* Ecclesiastical and Classical Pronunciations. 

The initial narrator (the voice of Santa Claus) uses Classical Pronunciation, as do all people from Christmas Town, while the people of Halloween Town use the Ecclesiastical Pronunciation.

The text has been rendered masterfully by Stefano Vittori in true Ancient Roman poetic meter, the very soul of Latin, so well as to surpass the power of even the original lyrics.

title: Velociraptor vs Tarbosaurus: Prehistoric Planet DUBBED in LATIN
description:
Prehistoric Planet  a documentary streaming television series about the ancient world in the Late Cretaceous Period: dinosaurs, pterosaurs, mosasaurs, and plesiosaurs are the subject matter. It set out to depict dinosaurs using current palaeontological research such as feathered dinosaurs. 

In this scene from the series, we see Velociraptor mongoliensis hunt lizards near a pride of sleeping Tarbosaurs. I have dubbed it into Latin and added back the music and sound effects. Enjoy!

title: Dog Anatomy in Latin
description:
Dazzle is a former racing greyhound whom my sister rescued some years ago. She is very sweet, and likes to sleep on the couch. Due to her racing career, she is easily startled, but seems to be calmed by the sound of Latin. Please enjoy this short video in which she teaches us some very basic dog anatomy. 

Does your dog also enjoy being spoken to in Latin? It's a great way for you to practice the language with someone who won't judge your language ability. Let me know in the comments!

title: Is Greek or Latin better? (spoken Ancient Greek) Â· Î Î¿Ï„Î­ÏÎ± á¼€Î¼ÎµÎ¯Î½Ï‰Î½ ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¯Î½;
description:
Which do you prefer: Ancient Greek or Latin? Which one is better, and why? In this video, I'll pose these questions to you in spoken Ancient Greek! The term "Ancient Greek" applies primarily to the language of those who wrote the literature of the Greek language from approximately 800 BC to 600 AD. The Ancient Greek in this video conforms with most standards of Classical Attic (5cBC - 4cBC) and Koine (4cBC - 6cAD), *both* of which are part of Ancient Greek, and constitute its normalized variant.

*Pronunciation notes: This video uses the Lucian Pronunciation of Ancient Greek, which is a reconstruction of the historical sound of Greek during the first centuries of the Roman Empire. This pronunciation system is explained in detail in my video on the Lucian Pronunciation here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dt9z5Gvp3MM

And my research into Ancient Greek phonology is summarized in this public spreadsheet of mine, Ranieri's Greek Pronunciation Chronology: https://bit.ly/ranierigreekpronunciation

The methology in determining this historical pronunciation, and the reasons for choosing it over other standards, is explained in the above linked Lucian Pronunciation video. title: Duck Anatomy in Latin - Lingua Latina Comprehensibilis
description:
Let's learn about the anatomy of the duck in Latin. Ducks have wings and feet. How do you say "to fly" or "to swim" in Latin? What's the word for duck and duckling in Latin? This video will teach you this and more.

ğŸ”Š If you like ducks, you'll love the audiobook I co-wrote with Irene La Preziosa, FABVLA ANATINA: https://luke-ranieri.myshopify.com/collections/frontpage/products/fabula-anatina-a-duckish-tale-in-latin ğŸ¦† ğŸ¥ 

ğŸ¦† Companion video to this one for April Fools' Day 2022: https://youtu.be/bBTymD3fgkQ

LINGVA LATINA COMPREHENSIBILIS is a series of Latin lessons for beginners teaching the Latin language in Latin, with the goal of instilling basic conversation and auditory comprehension, designed to accompany the popular Lingua Latina Per Se Illustrata series by Hans H. Ã˜rberg. Lingua Latina Comprehensibilis may be used by students learning on their own or by teachers in the classroom.

title: Colors: Black & White Â· Lingua Latina Comprehensibilis
description:
There is more than one word for "black" and more than one word for "white." The difference between the Latin color terms Äter, niger, albus, and candidus is often obscured in textbooks. Hopefully this video will shed some light on the discussion. â˜¯ï¸ 

Detailed discussion on the color terms for "black" : https://latinitium.com/latin-dictionaries/?t=do59
And for "white" :
https://latinitium.com/latin-dictionaries/?t=do26

title: Sally's Song in Latin, Nightmare Before Christmas ğŸƒ (lyrics: Stefano Vittori)
description:
The Nightmare Before Christmas in Latin! Incubus Ante NÄtÄlem. 
SALLY'S SONG Â· REGILLAE CARMEN
lyrical translation by Stefano RVMAK Vittori ğŸŒ 
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCKsXlPwvq17rQ2tIcixwRZw
performed by Aurora Van Bel ğŸŒ… 
Music design by Chris PERNOX Davis ğŸŒš
https://www.youtube.com/pernox
Edited by Luke SCORPIO Ranieri ğŸ¦‚ 
https://youtube.com/ScorpioMartianus

This unique and fascinating performance of the beloved song from Danny Elfman and Tim Burton's 1993 "The Nightmare Before Christmas" incorporates *both* Ecclesiastical and Classical Pronunciations. 

In this performance Aurora Van Bel uses a Late Latin pronunciation similar to the one heard at the end of Luke's performance of "Jack's Lament" ( https://youtu.be/iQleLmFkZAo ), which is a transitional stage between Classical and Ecclesiastical Latin. This is to emphasize Jack's discontent with either the Halloween or Christmas world, and ultimately to signify that the unique, the special melody of existence he seeks is in the very voice of Sally. Sally is what he longs for, and she for him.

The text has been rendered masterfully by Stefano Vittori in true Ancient Roman poetic meter, the very soul of Latin, so well as to surpass the power of even the original lyrics.

ğŸƒ  See our songs from The Nightmare Before Christmas in Latin! at this playist of my videos: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLU1WuLg45SiwuGR1H6ZRhLvusm1iQN7ay

Thank you so much for *sharing* this video with as many people and in as many places as you can! ğŸ‘» â˜ƒï¸

To fully appreciate the incredible music of the original movie, see this video by @Sideways https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w0GQlIOSi60 ğŸ§›â€â™‚ï¸ 

Translated by Stefano Vittori

SpÄ«rante in ventÅ sÄ“nsibus
quiddam servÄtum in nÅs venit.
Et, quamvÄ«s esse Å«nÄ volÅ,
nÅn solvÅ cor praesÄgiÅ:
ad portam stat; mÄtÅ«ruit.

Id lentus sentÄ«s,
quod nÅs adfÄ“cit?
At tÅ« nescÄ«s,
quid nÅbÄ«s ipse sÄ«s,
et lentus praeterÄ«s.

MÄ« cÄrum pignus quÅ ruit?
QuÅ multÅs Å«nus corripit?
FautrÄ«cem sÄ« fautrÄ«cibus
cÅnfundÅ vÅcem vÅcibus,
vÄ“cors paeÄn obmÅ«tuit.

At cum nÅn nÅlÄ“s,
candÄ“scent sÅlÄ“s.
At tÅ« nÅn vÄ«s.
et tÅ« nÅ«mquam volÄ“s.
At tÅ« nÅn noster es.

Comment:

Now RÄ“gilla is alone, far from society, which doesn't understand her: they're multÄ«, without a true critical personality, and follow their Å«nus. They're victims of this latter's foolish dream inspired by some deus nÅn bene advocÄtus, who filled their voices with a vÄ“cors paeÄn. She's also far from his beloved one. She's the sole who truly loves him, prÅ quÅ eÄ« sunt magna bella pugnÄta, but he is a Narcissist who loves himself and because of that he prefers the superficial admiration of the masses. He's also lentus, something Ovid's Penelope says of Ulixes. He doesn't come to her and doesn't come back to her, who pertains to him since the very beginning of time. The song is full of Catullus of Ovid's spirit. Metrically speaking, the syllables are all long but the penultimate, which is like a breath break after a doubt. Even among the simple vowels there's a high amount of long ones: the song has few verses but the time is suspended. A brief, yet everlasting, desperate, heart breaking cry of love.

title: Amadeus dubbed into Latin
description:
This dub into Latin of a scene from Amadeus is one of the first videos I ever created for YouTube. Originally uploaded to a different channel in July, 2008, I made it before ScorpioMartianus existed. I am re-uploading it to this channel with improved video quality; the audio quality is low, as I made this with a much more primitive microphone at the time. Thank you for your understanding, and enjoy!

title: Live from Latium! with Stefano Vittori & Marina Garanin
description:
Let's have a live converstion in LATIN with Marina Garanin & Stefano Vittori! Subscribe to their channels:

â¡ï¸ https://youtube.com/MusaPedestris
â¡ï¸ https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCKsXlPwvq17rQ2tIcixwRZw

Marina writes poems in German, English, and now Latin! Marina is also very adept at reciting Latin poetry, and in our livestream we will share some of our favorite Latin poems and recite them together, and also listen to Marina reciting some of her original poetry in Latin.

Marina is a published poet of German poetry; you can buy her book Der Knopf here:

ğŸ“– https://www.kurpfaelzischer-verlag.de/verlagsprogrammneu%20%282%29.htm

ğŸ“–  https://www.amazon.de/Knopf-Gedichte-Marina-Garanin/dp/3924566283/ref=sr_1_1?__mk_de_DE=%C3%85M%C3%85%C5%BD%C3%95%C3%91&dchild=1&keywords=der+knopf+marina+garanin&qid=1617134174&sr=8-1

Stefano Vittori is the undisputed master of translating popular songs into Latin. From his use of meter to his mastery of Latin literature, his lyrics are moving and often more powerful than the original English songs. Here are some of his amazing pieces:

Hellfire https://youtu.be/H0c1QNWH1H8

This is Halloween https://youtu.be/5bu4PVbzDlg

title: Learn Latin Live! Beginner Conversational Latin: Greetings
description:
Learn Latin Live! Beginner Conversational Latin for people with little or no experience with reading or speaking Latin. This livestream will be conducted in Latin, and those present will interact with me as students in a classroom in a low pressure, highly relaxed environment, giving you the chance to learn to speak Latin TODAY! ğŸ˜ƒ 

We will be using the famous book by Traupman: Conversational Latin for Oral Proficiency, which you can find on Amazon here:

title: Live from Tennessee! Paris: the Latin capital of the South (skip to 2min13sec for sound!)
description:
Join me as we enjoy a live conversation with Alexius CosÄnus (Alessio Schiano) and Gemma Lawless, a true power couple who live their lives in Latin: they speak Latin with each other at home daily, and they teach Latin in Latin to students of all ages. Alexius is also a very impressive Modern Latin poet who has composed hundreds of poems in Latin with, in my opinion, the skill of Ovid and the creativity of Horace.

00:00:00 Skip to 2min13 (no sound in beginning)
00:02:13 Start here! Tech difficulties with sound in beginning

Subscribe to Alexius's channel where he uploads new content in Latin almost every day, including really interesting vlogs about any topic imaginable:
â¡ï¸ https://youtube.com/alexiuscosanus

Alexius's poetry in Latin can be found here: 
ğŸ“š  https://facebook.com/AlexiusCosanus

ğŸ–Š  And even more of his poems can be found here:
https://sites.google.com/site/cosanusaeger/home/carmina/carmina-mensis-selecta/i

In our chat, the three us will discuss (in Latin!) the challenges and rewards of teaching Latin in full immersion, and also talk about Alexius' poetry and what this might mean for the continued rivival of the Latin language in the modern era.

title: Live in Latin w/ Stefano Vittori & Marina Garanin! | Translating Songs into Latin
description:
Let's have a live converstion in LATIN with Marina Garanin & Stefano Vittori! Subscribe to their channels:

â¡ï¸ https://youtube.com/MusaPedestris
â¡ï¸ https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCKsXlPwvq17rQ2tIcixwRZw

Marina writes poems in German, English, and now Latin! Marina is also very adept at reciting Latin poetry, and in our livestream we will share some of our favorite Latin poems and recite them together, and also listen to Marina reciting some of her original poetry in Latin.

Marina is a published poet of German poetry; you can buy her book Der Knopf here:

ğŸ“– https://www.kurpfaelzischer-verlag.de/verlagsprogrammneu%20%282%29.htm

ğŸ“–  https://www.amazon.de/Knopf-Gedichte-Marina-Garanin/dp/3924566283/ref=sr_1_1?__mk_de_DE=%C3%85M%C3%85%C5%BD%C3%95%C3%91&dchild=1&keywords=der+knopf+marina+garanin&qid=1617134174&sr=8-1

Stefano Vittori is the undisputed master of translating popular songs into Latin. From his use of meter to his mastery of Latin literature, his lyrics are moving and often more powerful than the original English songs. Here are some of his amazing pieces:

Hellfire https://youtu.be/H0c1QNWH1H8

This is Halloween https://youtu.be/5bu4PVbzDlg

Jack's Lament https://youtu.be/iQleLmFkZAo

What's This https://youtu.be/iQleLmFkZAo

Be Prepared https://youtu.be/s-jdNS95Rm0

Can You Feel the Love Tonight https://youtu.be/5LW0Nw7asoE

Thank You https://youtu.be/l37cqX2jBhE

Subscribe to Stefano Vittori's channel RUMAK here: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCKsXlPwvq17rQ2tIcixwRZw

title: OLD SERIES | Master of Egypt â€¢ Ancient Greek in Action! ep.12 | Athenaze Chapter 1 Preparation
description:
Update October 2025: The Ancient Greek in Action series has been rebooted, and you can see the first epsiode here: https://youtu.be/wYxRQv_qZiA

The original run of AGIA (Ancient Greek in Action) was designed as a way to prepare the viewer for Chapter 1 of the Athenaze graded reader.  The twelve AGIA episodes from 2020-2021 are still useful for that purpose, and also helpful in learning a suite of important grammar and vocabulary.  However, I decided in the rebooted series to craft a course with improved paedagogical methods, taking fuller advantage of the audiovisual medium, and not related to another course or book.  I also now use Classical Attic Pronunciation as my preferred pronunciation for paedagogical reasons, rather than the Samosatene Lucian Pronunciation you hear in the original run of AGIA.  All of these, however, are useful pronunciations, tools, and approaches.

************

Learn Ancient Greek through comprehensible input! By watching every video in this series in order, you should be able to understand everything after watching a video two or three times. In this way, you will build a strong foundation in Ancient Greek. Ancient Greek includes both Classical Attic Greek and Biblical Koine Greek.

title: Passover & Easter text reading in Latin & Greek! Live with Chris "Pernox" Davis | Greek thru Latin
description:
Join us for a reading in Latin and Greek of the Biblical texts corresponding to the traditional celebrations of Passover and Easter. All are welcome to join the livestream: the scope of this reading is not religious, but meant as a reading of literature for the purpose of learning Latin and Ancient Greek.

The New Testament text will be drawn from the Gospel of John; this is my audiobook of the entire gospel: https://luke-ranieri.myshopify.com/collections/frontpage/products/gospel-of-john-english-latin-greek-trilingual-audiobook-text

The Old Testament text is from Exodus 11 & 12, which is comes with my trilingual audiobook of the story of Passover: https://luke-ranieri.myshopify.com/collections/frontpage/products/passover-exodus-11-12-english-latin-greek-trilingual-audiobook-text

Normally Chris and I read the book Alexandros on Sundays, but this is a special livestream in the Ancient Greek in Latin series.

title: Live in Latin with Alexius & Gemma! Modern Latin Poetry; Teaching Latin in Latin; Pedagogy
description:
Join me as we enjoy a live conversation with Alexius CosÄnus (Alessio Schiano) and Gemma Lawless, a true power couple who live their lives in Latin: they speak Latin with each other at home daily, and they teach Latin in Latin to students of all ages. Alexius is also a very impressive Modern Latin poet who has composed hundreds of poems in Latin with, in my opinion, the skill of Ovid and the creativity of Horace.

Subscribe to Alexius's channel where he uploads new content in Latin almost every day, including really interesting vlogs about any topic imaginable:
â¡ï¸ https://youtube.com/alexiuscosanus

Alexius's poetry in Latin can be found here: 
ğŸ“š  https://facebook.com/AlexiusCosanus

ğŸ–Š  And even more of his poems can be found here:
https://sites.google.com/site/cosanusaeger/home/carmina/carmina-mensis-selecta/i

In our chat, the three us will discuss (in Latin!) the challenges and rewards of teaching Latin in full immersion, and also talk about Alexius' poetry and what this might mean for the continued rivival of the Latin language in the modern era.

title: OLD SERIES | Accusative Case & Singular Verbs â€¢ Ancient Greek in Action! ep.10
description:
Update October 2025: The Ancient Greek in Action series has been rebooted, and you can see the first epsiode here: https://youtu.be/wYxRQv_qZiA

The original run of AGIA (Ancient Greek in Action) was designed as a way to prepare the viewer for Chapter 1 of the Athenaze graded reader.  The twelve AGIA episodes from 2020-2021 are still useful for that purpose, and also helpful in learning a suite of important grammar and vocabulary.  However, I decided in the rebooted series to craft a course with improved paedagogical methods, taking fuller advantage of the audiovisual medium, and not related to another course or book.  I also now use Classical Attic Pronunciation as my preferred pronunciation for paedagogical reasons, rather than the Samosatene Lucian Pronunciation you hear in the original run of AGIA.  All of these, however, are useful pronunciations, tools, and approaches.

************

Learn Ancient Greek through comprehensible input! By watching every video in this series in order, you should be able to understand everything after watching a video two or three times. In this way, you will build a strong foundation in Ancient Greek. Ancient Greek includes both Classical Attic Greek and Biblical Koine Greek.

This episode reviews important topics from the previous lessons, especially grammatical gender terms, teaches the terms for singular, dual, and plural, and finally shows us that the dual may be replaced by the plural, as it is in most occurrences in Ancient Greek. The dual will therefore rarely be used again in this series, but the memory of it from the earliest videos, anchored forever in the mind with kittens and turtles and birdies, will allow the student to recognise the dual instantly and effortlessly in any text in the future. The peculiar behavior of the plural neuter, which uses singular verbs, is also explained entirely in context. The words for "why," "because," "do you understand" and "I understand" are taught.

Subtitles are only placed where they are necessary for the desired level of comprehension, which is primarily *auditory*; nevertheless, if you are interested in seeing the transcript: the entire book for this series can be found here:

title: OLD SERIES | Ancient Greek Commands | Ancient Greek in Action! ep.7
description:
Update October 2025: The Ancient Greek in Action series has been rebooted, and you can see the first epsiode here: https://youtu.be/wYxRQv_qZiA

The original run of AGIA (Ancient Greek in Action) was designed as a way to prepare the viewer for Chapter 1 of the Athenaze graded reader.  The twelve AGIA episodes from 2020-2021 are still useful for that purpose, and also helpful in learning a suite of important grammar and vocabulary.  However, I decided in the rebooted series to craft a course with improved paedagogical methods, taking fuller advantage of the audiovisual medium, and not related to another course or book.  I also now use Classical Attic Pronunciation as my preferred pronunciation for paedagogical reasons, rather than the Samosatene Lucian Pronunciation you hear in the original run of AGIA.  All of these, however, are useful pronunciations, tools, and approaches.

************

Learn Ancient Greek through comprehensible input! By watching every video in this series in order, you should be able to understand everything after watching a video two or three times. In this way, you will build a strong foundation in Ancient Greek. Ancient Greek includes both Classical Attic Greek and Biblical Koine Greek.

This lesson is taken from the Polis method by Christophe Rico, and you can find his book "Polis" on Amazon here: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/9657698006/ref=as_li_qf_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=lukeranieri-20&creative=9325&linkCode=as2&creativeASIN=9657698006&linkId=5e409cb66b3d12bef18d0ba0ec7dd826

 *IN IGNI*
HELLFIRE
lyrics by Stefano Vittori

Beata Maria,
scis esse mihi animam
tam rectam, ut qua jure gaudeam,

beata Maria,
et jure me majorem quam
lascivum vulgus reri audeam.

Dic mihi, Maria:
si saltantem cerno, cur
ejus oculus me ustilat?

Perceptae, conspectae  
sol nigro crine nectitur
et in me deflagrando furiat.   

In igni   Maligni hoc corpus ardet, nec
furores indigni peccata pellunt haec.

Nec error est nec criminor: 
nam strix Athingana comburit aegrum cor.
 
Nec criminor, si, Domine,
fecisti Satan fortiorem homine. 

Defende, Maria,
me a sirenis vocibus:
remota nobis illa taeda sit!

Confuta Smaragdam
et addic flammis acribus
aut in hac una manu prae da sit.  

Minister Frollo, Athingana fugit.
-Quid?
Nusquam in Cathedrali invenitur. Disparuit.
-Sed quomodo? Aliud cura. Apage, carnifex! Eam inveniam, etiam si opus erit totius Lutetiae Parisiorum crematione! 

Maligni cum igni est atro tibi res.
Aut mea aut ligni: alterutrius es! 

Miserere ejus, miserere mei, 
sed aut praeda mea aut ligni est!

English Translation

Beata Maria,
Beata Maria,
scis esse mihi animam
you know that I have a soul
tam rectam, ut qua jure gaudeam,
which is so righteous that I'm justly delighted of it.

beata Maria,
beata Maria,
et jure me maiorem quam
and, that I'm superior than
lascivum vulgus reri audeam.
the lascivous folk, I justly dare to think.

Dic mihi, Maria:
Tell me, Maria:
si saltantem cerno, cur
if I see her dancing, why
ejus oculus me ustilat?
her eye burns me?

Perceptae, conspectae
When I perceive her, when I look at her,
sol nigro crine nectitur
the sun is intertwined with her black hair,
et in me deflagrando furiat.
and while it burns in me, it drives me crazy.

In igni Maligni hoc corpus ardet, nec
In Satan's fire this body burns, and
furores indigni peccata pellunt haec.
the perverted craziness can't drive away this sin.

Nec error est nec criminor:
It's not a fault, I'm not guilty:
nam strix Athingana comburit aegrum cor.
It is the gipsy witch who burns my ill heart.

Nec criminor, si, Domine,
I'm not guilty, my Lord,
fecisti Satan fortiorem homine.
if you created Satan stronger than man.

Defende, Maria,
Protect me, Maria,
me a sirenis vocibus:
from the siren's voices:
remota nobis illa taeda sit!
may that torch be kept away from me!

Confuta Smaragdam
Condemn Esmeralda
et addic flammis acribus
and sentence her to the ferocious flames,
aut in hac una manu praeda sit.
or may she be prey of this sole hand.
Maligni cum igni est atro tibi res.
With Satan's dark fire you have to do.
Aut mea aut ligni: alterutrius es!
Either to me or to the pyre: you pertain to one of these two.

Miserere ejus, miserere mei, sed aut praeda mea aut ligni est!
Have mercy of me, have mercy of her, but she is either my prey or of the pyre.

title: OLD SERIES | Roman Empire in Ancient Greek | Ancient Greek in Action! ep.6
description:
Update October 2025: The Ancient Greek in Action series has been rebooted, and you can see the first epsiode here: https://youtu.be/wYxRQv_qZiA

The original run of AGIA (Ancient Greek in Action) was designed as a way to prepare the viewer for Chapter 1 of the Athenaze graded reader.  The twelve AGIA episodes from 2020-2021 are still useful for that purpose, and also helpful in learning a suite of important grammar and vocabulary.  However, I decided in the rebooted series to craft a course with improved paedagogical methods, taking fuller advantage of the audiovisual medium, and not related to another course or book.  I also now use Classical Attic Pronunciation as my preferred pronunciation for paedagogical reasons, rather than the Samosatene Lucian Pronunciation you hear in the original run of AGIA.  All of these, however, are useful pronunciations, tools, and approaches.

************

Learn Ancient Greek through comprehensible input! By watching every video in this series in order, you should be able to understand everything after watching a video two or three times. In this way, you will build a strong foundation in Ancient Greek. Ancient Greek includes both Classical Attic Greek and Biblical Koine Greek.

ğŸ¢ ANCIENT GREEK IN ACTION ğŸ› 
by Luke Amadeus Ranieri ğŸ¦‚ Î›Î¿ÏÎºÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ Ì£Î˜ÎµÏŒÏ†Î¹Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¿¬á¾±Î½Î¹Î®ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚  

ğŸº  Complete Ancient Greek in Action playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLU1WuLg45SixsonRdfNNv-CPNq8xUwgam

ğŸ¦ LESSON NOTES
This lessons builds on the foundation carefully laid by the previous 5 lessons. Since we are familiar with nouns in all genders, numbers, and declensions, we are at last free to explore sentences in context! And of course, what could be beter than following the model of the first chapter of LLPSI Familia Romana which so expertly teaches Latin (for which see: https://youtu.be/UQCo7_YAn_M ).

In this lesson we learn the the verb "to be" in singular (á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶), dual (á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¸Î½), and plural (Îµá¼°Ïƒá½¶), and while doing so we review from the previous lessons how to answer "how many" (Ï€ÏŒÏƒÎ¿Î¹), and are introduced to the question words "where?" (Ï€Î¿á¿¦) and "what?" (Ï„Î¯). Yes/no interrogatives á¼†ÏÎ± and á¼†ÏÎ± Î¼á½´ are taught in context. We also learn "but" (á½°Î»Î»á½°) and how it compares with the uniquely Ancient Greek pairing Î¼á½²Î½...Î´á½² which roughly equates to "on the one hand...on the other hand." We also learn locative with the dative case, how to say many and few (á½€Î»Î¯Î³Î¿Î¹, Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î¿á½¶), and lean the difference between a land and a Roman province.

The Dual is *not* a mandatory form in Ancient Greek, since the regular Plural may be used in place of the Dual even for two of a thing. Thus Ï„á½¼ Ï€Î¿Ï„Î±Î¼á½¼ may be rendered as Î¿á¼± Ï€Î¿Ï„Î±Î¼Î¿á½¶ even for two rivers. This overlap will be clarified in later lessons. The Dual form is used with increasing rarity through the centuries of Ancient Greek (roughly 9th century BC to 6th century AD).

The original run of AGIA (Ancient Greek in Action) was designed as a way to prepare the viewer for Chapter 1 of the Athenaze graded reader.  The twelve AGIA episodes from 2020-2021 are still useful for that purpose, and also helpful in learning a suite of important grammar and vocabulary. LESSON NOTES
This lesson introduces nouns of the Third Declension, including the dual form, just as for the First and Second Declension in the previous videos. Like the First and Second Declensions, Third Declension nouns may be masculine, feminine, or neuter. The key to understanding Ancient Greek gender and number is, as always, tied to the article, which always tells us exactly what gender and number a noun is. 
The Dual is not a mandatory form in Ancient Greek, since the regular Plural may be used in place of the Dual even for two of a thing. Thus Ï„á½¼ Î»Î­Î¿Î½Ï„Îµ may be rendered as Î¿á¼± Î»Î­Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ even for two lions. This overlap will be clarified in later lessons. The Dual form is used with increasing rarity through the centuries of Ancient Greek (roughly 9th century BC to 6th century AD).

Subtitles are only placed where they are necessary for the desired level of comprehension, which is primarily *auditory*; nevertheless, if you are interested in seeing the transcript: the entire book for this series can be found here:

title: This is Halloween, in LATIN! Nightmare Before Christmas (lyrics: Stefano Vittori) Songs in Latin
description:
The Nightmare Before Christmas in Latin! Incubus Ante NÄtÄlem. 
THIS IS HALLOWEEN Â· MVNDVS PATEAT

Luke SCORPIO Ranieri ğŸ¦‚ 
https://youtube.com/ScorpioMartianus

This unique and fascinating performance of the beloved song from Danny Elfman and Tim Burton's 1993 "The Nightmare Before Christmas" incorporates *both* Ecclesiastical and Classical Pronunciations. 

The initial narrator (the voice of Santa Claus) uses Classical Pronunciation, as do all people from Christmas Town, while the people of Halloween Town use the Ecclesiastical Pronunciation.

The text has been rendered masterfully by Stefano Vittori in true Ancient Roman poetic meter, the very soul of Latin, so well as to surpass the power of even the original lyrics.

ğŸƒ  See our songs from The Nightmare Before Christmas in Latin! at this playist of my videos: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLU1WuLg45SiwuGR1H6ZRhLvusm1iQN7ay

Thank you so much for *sharing* this video with as many people and in as many places as you can! ğŸ‘» â˜ƒï¸

title: OLD SERIES | Ancient Greek: Grammatical Gender, 1st masc, 2nd fem | Ancient Greek in Action! ep.4
description:
Update October 2025: The Ancient Greek in Action series has been rebooted, and you can see the first epsiode here: https://youtu.be/wYxRQv_qZiA

The original run of AGIA (Ancient Greek in Action) was designed as a way to prepare the viewer for Chapter 1 of the Athenaze graded reader.  The twelve AGIA episodes from 2020-2021 are still useful for that purpose, and also helpful in learning a suite of important grammar and vocabulary.  However, I decided in the rebooted series to craft a course with improved paedagogical methods, taking fuller advantage of the audiovisual medium, and not related to another course or book.  I also now use Classical Attic Pronunciation as my preferred pronunciation for paedagogical reasons, rather than the Samosatene Lucian Pronunciation you hear in the original run of AGIA.  All of these, however, are useful pronunciations, tools, and approaches.

************

Learn Ancient Greek through comprehensible input! By watching every video in this series in order, you should be able to understand everything after watching a video two or three times. In this way, you will build a strong foundation in Ancient Greek. Ancient Greek includes both Classical Attic Greek and Biblical Koine Greek. ğŸº 

ğŸ¢ ANCIENT GREEK IN ACTION ğŸ› 
by Luke Amadeus Ranieri ğŸ¦‚ Î›Î¿ÏÎºÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ Ì£Î˜ÎµÏŒÏ†Î¹Î»Î¿Ï‚ Î¡á¾±Î½Î¹Î®ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚

Î•Î¯Î½Î±Î¹ Î´Î¹Î±Ï†Î¿ÏÎµÏ„Î¹ÎºÎ® Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï†Î¿ÏÎ¬ Î±Ï€ÏŒ Î±Ï…Ï„Î® Ï€Î¿Ï… Î­Ï‡ÎµÏ„Îµ ÏƒÏ…Î½Î·Î¸Î¯ÏƒÎµÎ¹.  Î— Î›Î¿Ï…ÎºÎ¹Î±Î½Î® Î ÏÎ¿Ï†Î¿ÏÎ¬ ÎµÎ¯Î½Î±Î¹ Î¼Î¹Î± (Ï…Ï€Î¿Î¸ÎµÏ„Î¹ÎºÎ®) Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿ÏÎ¹ÎºÎ® Î±Î½Î±Î´Î·Î¼Î¹Î¿Ï…ÏÎ³Î¯Î± Ï„Î¿Ï… Î®Ï‡Î¿Ï… Ï„Ï‰Î½ Î‘ÏÏ‡Î±Î¯Ï‰Î½ Î•Î»Î»Î®Î½Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¬ Ï„Î· Î¡Ï‰Î¼Î±ÏŠÎºÎ® Î‘Ï…Ï„Î¿ÎºÏÎ±Ï„Î¿ÏÎ¯Î±.  Î£Î±Ï‚ ÎµÏ…Ï‡Î±ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Ï Î³Î¹Î± Ï„Î·Î½ Ï…Ï€Î¿Î¼Î¿Î½Î® ÎºÎ±Î¹ Ï„Î·Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î½ÏŒÎ·ÏƒÎ® ÏƒÎ±Ï‚. ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡· ğŸ˜Š 

Preliminary Lesson on the Ancient Greek Alphabet: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pr1laRMrw64

LESSON NOTES
Lesson 4 gives the terms for masculine, feminine, and neuter, and how to indentify them. 1st declension masculine nouns and 2nd declension feminine nouns are highlighted.

The Dual is not a mandatory form in Ancient Greek, since the regular Plural may be used in place of the Dual even for two of a thing. Thus Ï„á½¼ á½€ÏÎ½Î¹Î¸Î¯Ï‰ may be rendered as Ï„á½° á½€ÏÎ½Î¯Î¸Î¹Î± even for two birds. This overlap will be clarified in later lessons. The Dual form is used with increasing rarity through the centuries of Ancient Greek (roughly 9th century BC to 6th century AD).

Subtitles are only placed where they are necessary for the desired level of comprehension, which is primarily *auditory*; nevertheless, if you are interested in seeing the transcript: the entire book for this series can be found here:

ğŸ“–  https://bit.ly/ancientgreekinactionbook Ancient Greek in Action Book

*Pronunciation notes: This video uses the Lucian Pronunciation of Ancient Greek, which is a reconstruction of the historical sound of Greek during the first centuries of the Roman Empire. This pronunciation system is explained in detail in my video on the Lucian Pronunciation here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dt9z5Gvp3MM

And my research into Ancient Greek phonology is summarized in this public spreadsheet of mine, Ranieri's Greek Pronunciation Chronology: https://bit.ly/ranierigreekpronunciation

The methology in determining this historical pronunciation, and the reasons for choosing it over other standards, is explained in the above linked Lucian Pronunciation video. Please watch that video in its entirety, and familiarize yourself with the book Vox Graeca by W. Sidney Allen ( https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0521335558/ref=as_li_qf_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=lukeranieri-20&creative=9325&linkCode=as2&creativeASIN=0521335558&linkId=97ffa2a056f515e849efc3b2fc2a7903 ), as well as Greek: A History of the Language and its Speakers by Geoffrey C. Horrocks ( https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1118785150/ref=as_li_qf_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=lukeranieri-20&creative=9325&linkCode=as2&creativeASIN=1118785150&linkId=3b0d297bab9f772a0f3d9afb84129bf9 ) before commenting about the pronunciation used in this video. ğŸ˜Š Î§Î¬ÏÎ¹Î½ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰! title: OLD SERIES | Ancient Greek: Neuter Nouns of the 2nd Declension | Ancient Greek in Action! ep.3
description:
Update October 2025: The Ancient Greek in Action series has been rebooted, and you can see the first epsiode here: https://youtu.be/wYxRQv_qZiA

The original run of AGIA (Ancient Greek in Action) was designed as a way to prepare the viewer for Chapter 1 of the Athenaze graded reader.  The twelve AGIA episodes from 2020-2021 are still useful for that purpose, and also helpful in learning a suite of important grammar and vocabulary.  However, I decided in the rebooted series to craft a course with improved paedagogical methods, taking fuller advantage of the audiovisual medium, and not related to another course or book.  I also now use Classical Attic Pronunciation as my preferred pronunciation for paedagogical reasons, rather than the Samosatene Lucian Pronunciation you hear in the original run of AGIA.  All of these, however, are useful pronunciations, tools, and approaches.

************

Learn Ancient Greek through comprehensible input! By watching every video in this series in order, you should be able to understand everything after watching a video two or three times. In this way, you will build a strong foundation in Ancient Greek. Ancient Greek includes both Classical Attic Greek and Biblical Koine Greek. ğŸº

Lesson 3 introduces neuter nouns of the Second Declension. The Singular and Plural forms are introduced, as well as the Dual form.

ğŸ“–  https://bit.ly/ancientgreekinactionbook Ancient Greek in Action Book

The Dual is not a mandatory form in Ancient Greek, since the regular Plural may be used in place of the Dual even for two of a thing. Thus Ï„á½¼ á½€ÏÎ½Î¹Î¸Î¯Ï‰ may be rendered as Ï„á½° á½€ÏÎ½Î¯Î¸Î¹Î± even for two birds. This overlap will be clarified in later lessons. The Dual form is used with increasing rarity through the centuries of Ancient Greek (roughly 9th century BC to 6th century AD).

*Pronunciation notes: This video uses the Lucian Pronunciation of Ancient Greek, which is a reconstruction of the historical sound of Greek during the first centuries of the Roman Empire. This pronunciation system is explained in detail in my video on the Lucian Pronunciation here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dt9z5Gvp3MM

And my research into Ancient Greek phonology is summarized in this public spreadsheet of mine, Ranieri's Greek Pronunciation Chronology: https://bit.ly/ranierigreekpronunciation

The methology in determining this historical pronunciation, and the reasons for choosing it over other standards, is explained in the above linked Lucian Pronunciation video. Sidney Allen ( https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0521335558/ref=as_li_qf_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=lukeranieri-20&creative=9325&linkCode=as2&creativeASIN=0521335558&linkId=97ffa2a056f515e849efc3b2fc2a7903 ), as well as Greek: A History of the Language and its Speakers by Geoffrey C. title: Aeneid, book 1, vv. 64-80, recited by Dr. Balqis Al-Karaki (Vergil)
description:
Aeneid, recited by Balqis Al-Karaki, Ph.D, University of Jordan

I have enjoyed the distinct pleasure of having Dr. Al-Karaki as my student, and have guided her training in the Ranieri 5-stage Latin poetry scanning exercise, which can be found in this playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLQQL5IeNgck0-tQ4AZgKFMlQCJud_VY_H

Because she has learned the skill of reciting Latin poetry so excellently, Dr. Al-Karaki made these recordings at my request in order to provide outstanding examples of hexameter recited aloud that everyone can learn from.

You too can learn to recite poetry like myself and Dr. Al-Karaki with these videos ( https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLQQL5IeNgck0-tQ4AZgKFMlQCJud_VY_H ) ! Watch them all, and you will achieve success. ğŸ¤  ğŸ¦‚

title: Jack's Lament, in LATIN! Nightmare Before Christmas  (lyrics: Stefano Vittori) Songs in Latin
description:
This unique and fascinating performance of the beloved song from Danny Elfman and Tim Burton's 1993 "The Nightmare Before Christmas" incorporates *both* Ecclesiastical and Classical Pronunciations, utilized to convey Jack's sense of confidence mixed with confusion and doubt. The text has been rendered masterfully by Stefano Vittori in true Ancient Roman poetic meter, the very soul of Latin, so well as to surpass the power of even the original lyrics.

***

5-stage Poetry Scanning Exercise
00:00 Stage 1: monotone
01:05 Stage 2: ditonic inflexion
02:20 Stage 3: polytonal spoken inflexion over ditonic base
03:28 Stage 4: pseudo-spoken inflexion
04:28 Stage 5: recitation for performance

Purpose of the Verse Scanning Exercise: to acquire the natural rhythm of the Latin language (and thus its poetry) by damping the interference of one's native language tendencies through systematically deconstruction of the line into its most basic and important elements, rebuilding on top of this foundation the elements of normal speech.

N.B. Master each stage before proceeding to the next. Mastery of Stage 4 is required; mastery of Stage 5 is encouraged.

Stages explained
Stage 1: monotone (purpose: to divorce the verse from native language interference, permitting concentration on the language's most important building blocks: long and short syllables)
 - determine the correct syllable scansion of a given text from poetry by underlining the  long syllables with straight lines and the short syllables with curved lines
 - tap out the rhythm
 - produce the rhythm vocally in monotone with a singing syllable such as "la" or "ba"
 - sing the line of poetry in monotone, maintaining precise rhythm; a metronome may help 
Stage 2: ditonic inflexion (purpose: to reintroduce the second most important lexical feature of Latin, namely the stressed syllables, but using pitch instead of loudness; this helps the practitioner to further divorce the long syllables from the emphasized/stressed/accented syllables)
 - add acute accent marks to the stressed syllables of the text
 - as in stage 1, sing the line of poetry, but on the accented syllables raise the pitch by  some interval (such as a third, but any will do that is comfortable)
Stage 3: polytonal spoken inflexion over ditonic base (purpose: to reintroduce the natural prosody of speech while still artificially raising the pitch on every accented syllable)
 - as in stage 2, raise the pitch on the accented syllables, but allow the melody of the voice  to flow as natural speech between highs and lows
 - remember always to maintain strict long and short syllable rhythm; nothing is more  important
Stage 4: pseudo-spoken inflexion (purpose: to recite each line with normal spoken melody)
 - instead of raising the pitch on every accented syllable, allow normal lexical stress (which is not necessarily based on pitch, but is instead an increase in loudness) to take over
 - maintain correct syllable quantity at all times, with robotic adherence to the rhythm
 - each line should sound more or less like normal speech, expect that all natural pauses,  either based on punctuation, or interpretation by the practitioner, will be ignored
Stage 5: recitation for performance (purpose: to perform the piece for an audience)
 - rather than reciting each line of poetry as a strict rhythmical unit, break the text into  phrases according to the natural pauses of narrative
 - ensure each phrase is rhythmically correct
 - techniques include pauses at punctuation, and no pause at the end of a line if the phrase  continues semantically into the next line

The Verse Scanning Exercise is to be utilized for all poetry until Stage 4 can be attained at sight for any poem.

I have done my best in the audio recording to interpret the ancient texts and give a living voice to the meanings of these varied interjections. Other interpretations are possible, as well as other meanings that I did not explore in these slides. Thanks for watching!

If you have any comments about these interjections, or about others I missed, please leave a note below!

title: The Bible in 3 Greek & Latin Pronunciations! John 1:1-5 (JÅhannÄ“s â€¢ á¼¸Ï‰Î¬Î½Î½Î·Ï‚)

See more at Ranieri's Greek & Latin Pronunciation Chronology Spreadsheets! link:
https://bit.ly/RanieriGreekPronunciation
https://bit.ly/RanieriLatinPronunciation

- note: "Ranieri's Latin Pronunciation Chronology Spreadsheet" is still in its early stages, but I was still eager to experiment with the 4th century AD Latin pronunciation.

Note that the pronunciation of the erudite and the common people is virtually the same in most points of history, as demonstrated by Roger Wright's "Late Latin and Early Romance" (1982); only by the 9th century is there a distinct "Latin" versus "Romance". Thus my reconstruction of the Vulgate is meant to be the way that anyone would, more or less, have prononuced these sentences.

To that end, the historical reconstructions are best guesses based on the evidence I have available at this time. I hope my work will inspire others to do more of this type of recording, and to do better! â˜ºï¸ğŸ¦‚

- Macte! Duce tÄ“! DÅ«cÄs nÅs! DÅ«cÄ“s quÅ?

- QuidnÄ«? Quid nÅbÄ«s cum rÄ“gibus? Pereant rÄ“gÄ“s, pereant rÄ“gÄ“s! Bucca bucca bucca!

- Sibi sÄ« datur optimu' prÄ«nceps, 
quis enim quid alid cupiat?

mereÄs modo: plÅ«rima dÅ.

*****

The translation is made in Leonine verses (i.e. verses with both quantitative structure and rhyme). The structure of the song consists of a strophe, an antistrophe, and an epode. The strophe and the antistrophe are each composed of two distichs, where the first verse is made of two anapaestic feet (two short and one long syllable) followed by an Ionic Ä minÅre (two short and two long syllables) and the second verse is made of three anapaestic feet - so it's basically the same metre of the first one, in a catalectic form. The rhyme scheme for each of them is ABAB. 

This is also the scheme of the recitative strophe of the introduction. The epode is composed of three strophes: 

1) a distich identical to the preceding ones, with rhyme scheme AB, 

2) a strophe made of four verses consisting of an anapaestic foot followed by an Ionic Ä minÅre, with rhyme scheme AABB, 

3) a strophe made of five verses, the first two with the same metre as the preceding strophe, the second two with the same metre as the even verses of the distichs of the strophe and antistrophe, and the last consisting of a unique anapaest, with rhyme scheme AABCC. This structure is repeated twice, the two iterations being separated by a recitative prosastic part. In the original English version, the structure is the same but with amphibrachys (a foot less popular in Latin) instead of anapaests (except for the distich in the epode, which has anapaests and Ionics as well).

Scar's Latin is of an educated, archaizing type echoing the register of the original English. Traits of this register are: the fall of final /s/ after short vowels before words with consonantal onset ("hebentibu'" - a popular trait, hence shared by hyaenas' "optimu'"), obsolete nominal and verbal inflected forms ("fameÄ«", "faxÅ"), elevated Hellenisms ("dogmata", "logos" - in contrast with hyaenas' more trivial Hellenisms "euge", "sophÅs").

As an anti-Augustan, Scar also wants to appear as an "optimus princeps" (a term typical of the Augustan propaganda) and cites in the distichs of the epode the most important Author of that propaganda, Vergil, in particular the most propagandistic piece, Eclogae IV ("redeunt SÄturnia rÄ“gna / (oritur)(et) nova prÅgeniÄ“s", vv. 6-7; "aderit jam tempus(:) honÅr(um)(Ä“s)", v. 48, as well as "bona turba, favÄ“te mihÄ«", where "favÄ“te" echoes "casta favÄ“, LÅ«cÄ«na", v. 10). "Duce mÄ“/tÄ“" itself echoes "tÄ“ duce" of v. 13. "Per tempora dÅ«rÅ" echoes Catullus' "obstinÄtÄ mente perfer, obdÅ«rÄ" (8,10).

However, Scar's deepest nature is Epicurean. Hence, his true favorite poet is not Vergil, whom he uses only for political purposes, but Lucretius, as it's clear from his use of some of this poet's favorite terms, like "retinentia", and the S decidua itself.
